_chemical.ChemicalName: Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]
Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CHALMETTE REFINING, L.L.C.
Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary
LDEQ Facility ID:  1376
 
1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies     

The Chalmette Refining, L.L.C. process operations involve the handling, use, processing, or storage of hazardous materials that may present a certain degree of risk.  Chalmette has adopted certain safety precautions to prevent accidental on-site and off-site exposures.  These safety precautions include: 

7 Effectively managing our process operations;
7 Investing in the latest process safety technologies;
7 Training on an ongoing basis our personnel;
7 Reviewing our processes for hazards on a continuous basis;
7 Ensuring safety is considered in process design, installation, operations and maintenance; and
7 Training and maintaining a highly efficient Emergency Response Organization

By effectively managing the procedures, technology, and personnel interfaces that produce excellence in our operations, we minimize risks and thus effectively manage and minimize the impact of process related incidents.

Chalmette Refining, L.L.C. has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This is evidenced by our history of support and commitment to the community, our high environmental standards, and our participation in the ISO 9000 Quality Program.  We are proud of our Safety and Environmental Programs and continue to strive to be among the best in industry.

2. Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Chalmette Refining, L.L.C., located in Chalmette, LA, operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products (e.g. jet fuel, diesel fuel, kerosene, gasoline, LPG, and specialty chemicals) from raw Crude Oil.  These processes contain regulated flammable substances and flammable mixtures which may include: hydrogen, methane, ethane, propane, isobutane, butane, pentane, and hydrofluoric acid.  

3. Hazard Assessment Results

The RMP rule requires companies to dev

elop release scenarios that estimate the potential community impact from an accidental release.  These scenarios are useful for emergency planning in the event of an accident. There are two types of scenarios required by EPA, the worst-case scenario (WCS) and the alternative release scenario (ARS).  

The WCS is the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance.  It assumes the worst-case meteorological conditions that would allow the release to travel the greatest distance.  The WCS associated with toxic substances at the refinery is a rupture of the HF Alkylation Unit Acid Evacuation System, resulting in a release of hydrofluoric acid. 

The ARS allows industries to develop a more realistic emergency planning scenario.  The ARS associated with toxic substances is a 2" transfer hose failure, resulting in the release of hydrofluoric acid. 

The WCS associated with a release of flammable substances at the refinery is a vapor cloud explosion (VCE) involving a rupture of a LPG storage tank.  In this scenario pentane is assumed to release, completely vaporize, and ignite, resulting in a VCE.                                                                                      The ARS associated with flammable substances is a transfer hose failure resulting in a VCE due to a release of propane.

4.  Five Year Accident History

Three accidental releases of regulated toxic or flammable substances have occurred at Chalmette Refining, L.L.C. from covered processes within the last five (5) years. On 11/21/1996, a contract employee was injured due to exposure to hydrofluoric acid.  On 1/21/1997, four contract employees were injured during a flare fire and on 7/9/1997 a fire at the Hydrocracker Unit resulted in property damage.  No onsite fatalities, offsite injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, or property damage have occurred at the Chalmette Refinery. 

5. General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Following is a summary of the General Accidental Release

Prevention Program in place at Chalmette Refining, L.L.C.  The processes at the refinery that are regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA PSM standard, this summary addresses the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management systems in place to implement the accident prevention program.

5.1 Employee Participation.  The employees are consulted on the conduct and development of process hazards analyses and on other means of accident prevention.

5.2  Process Safety Information.  Chalmette Refining, L.L.C. maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of refinery processes.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  

5.3  Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).   PHA is an analytical process used for the identification and analysis of hazards in a process for the purpose of systematically evaluating the likelihood and consequences of accidents in order to develop recommendations to reduce and/or control risks.

Our objective in performing process hazards analyses is to help prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of acute, catastrophic releases of toxic and/or flammable/explosive materials in the Refinery operations. The process begins with the identification of credible hazards in our operations, detailed evaluation and assessment of the risks involved, and the implementation of measures to reduce the risk.

5.4 Operating Procedures.  Operating procedures provide accurate and practical instructions on how to carry out job duties safely.  These procedures are the primary source for understanding the process, and an integral tool for unit-specific training.

5.5 Training.  Training is the critical means used to ensure that all personnel involved in operating a process have and maintain the necessary knowledge and skills to conduct their jobs safe

ly.  Training occurs on two levels as indicated below:

5.6 Refinery-wide training consists of knowledge and skills necessary for all employees, regardless of unit, to understand or master.     

5.7 Unit specific training covers the skills and knowledge associated with the particulars of
individual unit operation.

5.8  Contractors.  Contractors are required to adhere to the same safety standards as the Chalmette 
Refinery employees.   The contractors receive equivalent safety training and information. 

5.9 Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs).  PSSRs are performed for new facilities and for modified facilities when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.

5.10  Mechanical Integrity.  Chalmette Refining, L.L.C. has established management controls to ensure that process equipment is designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to operate as required by the process.  Effective preventive and predictive maintenance programs and quality control systems for process equipment are necessary to ensure operability of the refinery and prevent or minimize the consequences of catastrophic releases. 

5.11 Safe Work Practices.   The Chalmette Refinery has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and public safety.  These practices are structured through our Environmental, Health and Safety Management Systems Program (EHSMS).  The EHSMS is structured as follows:

Element 1  Policy and Leadership        Element 7    Environmental Protection
Element 2  Continuous Improvement        Element 8    Product Stewardship
Element 3 Safety and Health        Element 9    Training
Element 4 Risk Management        Element 10    Community Relations
Element 5 Incident Investigating and Reporting        Element 11    Legal Requirements
Element 6 Crisis Preparedness        

5.12 Management of Change.  The Management of Change Procedure provides the necessary tools for a comprehensive review of all changes (except for "replacements in kind") affecting refinery processes

prior to implementation.  The reviews associated with it ensure that hazards are not introduced or existing safeguards eliminated which could result in catastrophic releases of toxic, reactive, flammable or explosive chemicals.

5.13 Incident Investigation.  An incident investigation is the process by which underlying causes of incidents and near misses are determined and steps are taken to prevent similar occurrences.  At the Chalmette Refinery all incidents are investigated.

5.14 Compliance Audits.  The Chalmette Refinery performs audits to self-evaluate the effectiveness of the Refinery Safety and Environmental Policies and Procedures and our compliance with OSHA PSM and EPA RMP.  

6. Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The processes at Chalmette Refining, L.L.C. have hazards that are managed to ensure 
continued safe operation.  The General Accidental Release Prevention Program in section 5 of this executive summary applies to all processes at the refinery.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent incidents from occurring.
In addition to the General Accidental Release Prevention Program elements, the Chalmette Refinery has safety features on its process units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of, or mitigate a release.

7.  Emergency Response Program Information

The Chalmette Refinery Emergency Response Plans serve as the final line of defense against
Accidental releases and other emergencies. The elements of the PSM/RMP program serve to prevent incidents and releases of highly hazardous material, our Emergency Response Plans serve as the guidelines for reacting to unwanted releases and other emergencies if and when they do 
occur.

8. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Chalmette Refining, L.L.C. continuously audits and develops improvement plans for its processes.  
Some of the planned changes for are as follows:

a.  LPG Risk Mitigation Project
This project was initia

ted to protect certain propane bullets and butane spheres in fire situation, and to improve the operability of certain propane bullets.  Specifics of this project are as follows:

7 Installation of emergency shut-down valves which automatically fail-close in a fire and that can be controlled remotely.
 
7 Installation of a fire protection sprinkler system for two propane bullet vessels and two propane loading pumps.
 
7 Modification of certain fire water system loops.
 
7 Modifications to tape and flow type level indicators. 

b. Installation of Infrared Hydrofluoric Acid vapor detection system
c. Installation of Hydrofluoric Acid Vapor Mitigation System
d. Validation of the Refinery Safety Procedures Manual
e. Improvement of incident investigation process

In addition, facility-siting considerations are included in the PHA process.
